    q=0.25 z=15
    q=0.30 z=24
    q=0.35 z=41
    q=0.40 z=89
    q=0.45 z=340

**12． 结论**

我们为无信任电子交易提出了一个系统。我们从数字签名币的常用框架开始，它对所有者有很强的控制，但是因为不能避免双花，所以还不完整。为了解决双花，我们提出了一个点对点的网络，这个网络使用工作量证明记录一个公共的交易历史，只要诚实节点控制大部分CPU算力，很快使得攻击者无法通过计算来改变交易历史。该网络的非结构化简单性使得它很稳健。节点同时工作，很少需要相互协调。他们不需要被识别，因为消息不需要路由到任何特定的位置，只需尽力传递就好。节点可以离开网络，也可以需要的时候重新加入网络，接受工作量链作为他离开的时候发生了什么的证据。他们用CPU算力投票，通过在有效区块上工作并延续它来表达对区块的接受，通过不在新区块上工作表示拒绝无效区块。任何需要的规则和激励都可以在这种共识机制下进行。

全文完

title: Mango integration, localnet testing and Anchor CPI to non Anchor programs
body:
So lately I’ve been tasked to integrate the Solana Program I’m working on with Mango.
I want to gather the knowledge and tidbits that I find valuable in case that can be of use.

*Sky Burial #2 by Wayne Haag, because space derelicts stuff look cool*


______

Mango is a decentralised exchange (DEX) that offer leveraged trading and perpetuals.

Mango is managed by a DAO and seems like a great functional example of decentralised governance.

And most importantly, it’s a neat product I use since months, my main DEX. Neat features and UI, smooth UX.


_____

## Localnet dev environment with --clone

In order to be productive, I want to iterate quickly.

Mango is currently accessible on `devnet` and `main-net` clusters, but my anchor workspace contains several projects, that I modify often, so I don’t feel like using `devnet`.

I want to be able to have my usual `anchor test` speed, not sure what happen behind the curtain but the deployments to `localnet` don’t event appear in the prompt, making it ideal for iterating fast.

In order to use Mango on `localnet` I found this neat option for `solana-test-validator` (the program running `localnet` coming with the Solana cli) :

`--clone <account>`  (credits to dvcrn#7961 on the Anchor discord)

It copies accounts from another cluster into the starting `localnet` instance, and note that once you run the `solana-local-validator` once, it create a `test-ledger` folder that store its state. So `--clone` only have effect when this `test-ledger` is not there, of if you use `--reset` to start fresh.

This is how I use it :

```
#!/bin/bash

# Reset then configure the local validator to mimic the mango accounts on devnet
solana-test-validator \
 --reset                                                `: # Reset the test-ledger` \
 --url https://mango.devnet.rpcpool.com                 `: # Cluster from which the below program will be cloned` \

I run that script once to configure my `localnet`, or to reset it.

You can then start you `solana-local-validator` the usual way, or run the above script each time if you want to have a deterministic environment.

You then call `anchor test --skip-local-validator` to ran your test suit against it (at first I though Anchor would pick up the local `test-ledger` but it doesn’t)

All the accounts come from the mango `ids.rs`

[https://github.com/blockworks-foundation/mango-client-v3/blob/main/src/ids.json](https://github.com/blockworks-foundation/mango-client-v3/blob/main/src/ids.json)


______

One neat additional thing you can do, is to also copy your wallets from the devnet in order to have the right tokens and balances :

```
--clone aca3VWxwBeu8FTZowJ9hfSKGzntjX68EXh1N9xpE1PC    `: # my wallet account (add yours too)` 
```

You can easily follow Mango tutorial to get Devnet tokens, then go trade these on the devnet Mango for other Sol, BTC and the like (That’s a good way to avoid the devnet sol airdrop limitation 🤫)

[https://docs.mango.markets/tutorials/how-to-receive-dev-net-tokens](https://docs.mango.markets/tutorials/how-to-receive-dev-net-tokens)

This allows me to send Mango instructions like `InitMangoAccount` successfully.

One last thing that I loose using `anchor test --skip-local-validator` compared to just running `anchor test` is that the deployment does prompt now, not as fast. Will look into that later to understand what’s the diff.


__________

## Anchor and CPI to Mango

Mango is not Anchor friendly, seems normal as the project is big and complex, and has been started from before Anchor. Also they probably don’t want to rely on a WIP framework.

Most of the “issues” here, are not really issues… Just sugar and QoL stuff, subjective.

First issues is that you cannot use the idiomatic Anchor stuff like `Program<‘info, Mango>` as mango did not have a declare_id required by Anchor.

Did a smol PR about it :

[https://github.com/blockworks-foundation/mango-v3/pull/67](https://github.com/blockworks-foundation/mango-v3/pull/67)


_____

### Creating and initialising the MangoAccount

The next thing is that the `mango::state::MangoAccount` has a span of 28912 bytes if I’m not mistaken, preventing you to use the Anchor IDL account creation :

```
    #[account(
        init,
        seeds = [MANGO_SEED, mint.key().as_ref()],
        bump,
        payer = authority,
        owner = mango::mango_program::Mango::id(), // This is my custom stuff added with the PR above
        space = MANGO_ACCOUNT_SPAN, // 28912
    )]
    pub mango_account: AccountInfo<'info>,
```

Results in this error :
`Account data size realloc limited to 10240 in inner instructions`

So I fall back on the associated instruction init as follows :

```
// ... In the Solana program
// signer cause it's required later for the CPI initialization 
#[account(mut, signer)]
pub mango_account: AccountInfo<'info>,
// ...
```

and in the typescript code

```
// ...
   const mangoAccount = new Keypair(); 
   const createMangoAccountIx = SystemProgram.createAccount({
      programId: MANGO_PROGRAM_ID,
      space: MangoAccountLayout.span,
      lamports: await getRentExemption(MangoAccountLayout.span),
      fromPubkey: admin.wallet.publicKey,
      newAccountPubkey: mangoAccount.publicKey, 
    });
    // Then call your program instruction and don't forget the IX + the mangoAccount.secretKey in the signers.
    // instructions: [createMangoAccountIx],
    // signers: [mangoAccount.secretKey],
// ...
```


_____

### Mint-erlude 🥂

For the next “Mango related” part, I will have to stop testing with my locally crafted mints, and start using the actual `devnet` token mints, so that the cloned accounts from the mango program can find their babies.

Here I go on `devnet` , I create a new wallet, fund it with some of the required tokens.

![r i c h](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/C7r_Z4yLnUpTe4oVh9cB3.png?height=352&width=1978)

Next step is to go in the script that setup the local environment for `localnet` and add this new account to the cloning.

```
// ...
--clone Eyh77zP5b7arPtPgpnCT8vsGmq9p5Z9HHnBSeQLnAFQi   `: # Test user wallet` \
// ...
```

Final step, is to go in the program and create the `Keypair` associated to these thanks to the exported Private Key. (We need keypair to sign stuff)

```
// ...
// aca3VWxwBeu8FTZowJ9hfSKGzntjX68EXh1N9xpE1PC
const aca3VWSeed = Uint8Array.from([
  197, 246, ... 146, 223,
]);
// Eyh77zP5b7arPtPgpnCT8vsGmq9p5Z9HHnBSeQLnAFQi
const Eyh77Seed = Uint8Array.from([
  219, 139, ... 212, 175,
]);

// Identities - both of these are wallets that exists on devnet, we clone them in the localnet env
aca3VWxwBeu8FTZowJ9hfSKGzntjX68EXh1N9xpE1PC
export let admin = Keypair.fromSecretKey(aca3VWSeed);
export let user = Keypair.fromSecretKey(Eyh77Seed);
// ...
```

Now I have my test identities that are funded and ready to be used.


_____

### Depositing to the Mango Account

I’ll update this article with the next part as I advance.

title: trading attitude refresh
body:
* my new goal is to maximize fluidity
  * i want my experience to be as frictionless, spontaneous, and in-flow as possible
  * a better way to say this is: i want to have fun
* i’ve found that any self-imposed rigid structures inevitably collapse
* my trading ethos is along these lines:
  * “every day, i assume every position i have is wrong” — Paul Tudor Jones
  * i am infinitely ignorant, per the arguments of Naval Ravikant
  * i disregard sunken costs; there is no such thing as wasted effort
* according to a far more experienced fund manager, with my tiny portfolio, it’s better to make plays with tactical, in-and-out opportunities such as flipping shitcoins rather than the long-term perspective i’m currently deploying
  * this is because my sizing is nimble and can easily play in smaller opportunities as needed
* until i’m a whale, i can leverage my strength of unlimited deployability
  * a large fund such as 3AC can’t act without incurring huge slippage, and opportunities of MCAP < 5-10 million aren’t even worth their time
* this is a convincing argument to me, and at the same time i think it makes sense for me to maintain (and develop invalidation points for) my current holdings
  * until i find invalidations for my original theses or superior opportunities, i’ll hold my current positioning
  * at the same time, i can use my remaining capital to gain familiarity with this faster, tactical approach: the grey jackal is an opportunistic omnivore

title: 小孩的英语学习之路-2021-10-09-两周年小结
body:
不知不觉已经陪同Suzy学习了两年的英文，在可预见的未来Suzy的英文水平应该会越来越好，奇怪的问题是，同样也是与Suzy一起学习，并未发现我的英文水平提高多少呢？反而我们一起学习过的英文单词，Suzy能记住，我却忘记了呢？这个真是有点令人“愉悦的忧伤”。愉悦Suzy在学习上的进步，忧伤自己在英文上原地踏步。是什么原因导致这个问题呢？粗略的总结一下，主要原因就是硬件和软件。从硬件上面来看，小孩的大脑正在处在开发阶段，很多空白区域等待开发，而且存储的速度和读取速度都比成人要快，好比就是一辆新车出来在高速路跑起来，与一辆了30年的车相比，那肯定是不一样的。另外一个软件方面的影响。小孩的对新的实物之间的理解和认识处在学习阶段，能通过全方位的接触来记忆这些单词，而成年人在学习和记忆方式上面已经固化了，很难改善。而且对于新的东西，好奇心的力量驱使记忆在大脑里面的神经连接也要强烈得多。或者说一个是主动学习与被动学习的区别或者效率的差异。另外一个主要的原因就是时间了，尽管我与Suzy大多数时间都在一起学习英文。但是除了我们一起学习英文的时间，Suzy常常看英文动画片（动画片的图像和声音同步播放，尽管有些时候Suzy不知道什么意思，但是看见一些东西，也自然能明白是什么意思，比如之前看动画片学习到parachute,看到一个降落伞落下来，有小动物在大叫 parachute，parachute，按照之前文章提到的大脑学习模式，以最简单的模式学习，很容易就关联起来parachute就是降落伞的意思。）和自己看英文课外书（尽管大多数时候是看的图片，但是在不经意间也会看里面的文字描述，这种情况下就让文字与图片关联在一起，加强了对这些英文的理解），基于以上原因，这就是我理解为什么同样是一起学习的人，为啥学习的效果有这么大的差别呢？

说到相关的总结经验，其中在之前每周的更新中多多少少都有提及到。既然是总结，还是要来一个总结，要不然怎么也说不过去。对不？伴随了两年的学习当中，我的感受就就有点像《舌尖上的中国》提到一句台词：高端的食材 往往只需要采用最朴素的烹饪方式。对应过来，学习英文的方法 往往只需要采用最简单的学习方式-持之以恒，以身作则。就这个八个字，我觉得就够了，这个就是干货中的干货，已经干得不能再干。能够坚持的人自然能明白其中的奥秘之处，不坚持或者没有真正参与的人可能就理解的不是那么深了。其实早在Suzy开始学习英文后的四个月后，我感觉学习效果还不错，就把Readingaz-AA这套书以及《英语启蒙第一年完全攻》送给很多身边的朋友们。后面的剧情大家都比较熟悉了，“坚持下来的家庭都是一样的，没有坚持下来的家庭各有各的不坚持的理由”。确实是这样的，太阳下面没有新鲜事情，学习这个事情本来就是比较简单的，并不需要太多的高科技或者搞智商，只要坚持简单重复就好了。这个差不多就是此次总结的内容。貌似有点少了，但是这个确实也是实际的情况。有道是：山不在高，有仙则灵。法不在多，能用就行。

回到Suzy的学习上来，本周还是一如既往的学习中，就是按照上面说的办法，每天读绘本，定时看英文动画片和自由看英文课外书。学习的过程是比较枯燥的，但是偶尔还是有很多的意外的快乐。比如本周的快乐如下：

在与Suzy一起学习的过程当中，学习到如下这边书的时候，里面提到这么一段话，

![](https://pic3.zhimg.com/v2-c17c8e86034f1e99592a3d3f3da6022a_b.jpg)

我就给Suzy解释，什么是Rhythm ,就是指押韵的意思，然后给她进行示范，下面这句话就是押韵的意思，然后我就让她想想有啥是押韵的呢？结果她一出口就来一句 Cat is fat.，效果还不错，后面我们一起想了一些，比如 Monkey is pinky， Dog is big，Mole is in the hole。这个练习可是有点烧脑的，没有一些词汇量还真玩不转这个。不行大家可以自己尝试来两个rhythm的句子，而且能表达准确的意思。

title: Seeing Like a Code: early interactions with DAOs
body:
### Creating new financial and governance systems is a political and social act, not a technocratic solution to an accepted problem, not a technical tool, although that’s where it starts.

*Seeing Like a State* by James C. Scott (1998) opens with the story of the invention of scientific forestry in 18th Century Prussia and Saxony. This is a model and a metaphor for the simplification and manipulation of the world by powerful institutions with sharply defined interests (such as nation states). In the case of forestry, the state’s tunnel vision is focused on resource extraction, translating the ancient forest into measurements of usable timber yield, and missing the other parts of the forest. Then, reshaping (clearing, ordering, replanting) forests to better suit measurement, administration and extraction of that resource. The ordered rows of single-species trees were, of course, catastrophic for the ecosystem.

*The instrument, the knife, that carved out the new, rudimentary forest was the razor-sharp interest in the production of a single commodity... Everything that seemed unrelated to efficient production was ignored. Having come to see the forest as a commodity, scientific forestry set about refashioning it as a commodity machine. (p.21)*

Top-down planning maps the world according to myopic short term interests. In Scott’s thesis this is the substrate to the tragic episodes of state development through the 20th Century, which combined the aspiration to the administrative ordering of nature and society, the use of power, and a weakened civil society lacking the capacity to resist. 
  
 It’s one of those non-fiction books where the author makes their claim and then delivers a regiment of chaptered illustrations in support. (Whisper: *This could have been an email*). I read it because it’s on the reading lists of many in the DAO community, and I’ve been doing a DAO course.

The world needs more larpers writing about DAOs like it needs a hole in the head. Except, such is the global network that the seeming cornucopia of discord servers bursting with DAO discourse represents people and ideas that are still in reality few and siloed.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/xy2hpwcQZZ6-ed3S9TW3Q.jpg?height=1353&width=2595)

A Distributed Autonomous Organisation (DAO) is decentralised and governed around rules enforced on a blockchain. The rules and the organisation are therefore transparent and immutable, open source and trustless. The DAO literature positions a sequence of old governance organisational structures, from tribes to hierarchies to markets, and locates DAOs (and coordinated decentralised decision-making more generally) next to and ripe for a global, post-corporate world.

DAOs have been described as *a discord (a gaming forum gone mainstream communication platform) with a shared bank account.* The majority are organised groups investing in digital assets, but beyond digital currency wealth, members value of the community of a DAO. There is wealth, too.  There was $10m in DAOs in 2019, and over $1B now.

*Seeing Like a State* is a DAO reading list favourite because it describes repeating failures of centralised top-down organisations and by default seems to welcome the DAO fundamentals of decentralisation, transparency and coordination in decision-making, work, and reward.

But, by another reading of the text, it is the language and methods of measurement that have so effectively shaped the actions and outcomes Scott describes. Decentralised Autonomous Organisations do the same; instead of the metrics of natural resources the language is ***rules that a machine can understand.***

There is a schism between the language of DAOs and the language of the DAOists. Articulate, genius DAOist trailblazers carry me along on their belief that a better way of coordinating is possible and it’s here.

[https://twitter.com/owocki/status/1448016316523286529?s=20](https://twitter.com/owocki/status/1448016316523286529?s=20)

Ewoki GITER of COINS (Kevin Owocki of Github DAO) spoke to my class from Colorado, beautifully, astutely, fluidly. At one point he paused and reminded us: *Well, you know, there are a lot of other aspects grafted onto employment structures we need to consider, security, sick leave and health insurance, pension systems, unions. The old system has some benefits.*

 The old system does have some benefits, although not for the globally connected 20-40 year old males who currently constitute the majority of the DAO community. We talk about this, too, the *problem of diversity*, the risk of a narrow group of people building the same infrastructure, following the same best practice applied across the board, with the same assumptions, the same solution to the same reading of the problem.  
  
 Even fluidly articulate Owocki shapes his compelling vision around the language of the technology that underpins it. Around tools, plug-ins, applications, perpetual rules that can’t be compromised, the ‘if then…’ clarity of the coder’s direction, the ability to fix scalability and coordination problems with clever technology.

[https://twitter.com/owocki/status/1448334880043982849?s=20](https://twitter.com/owocki/status/1448334880043982849?s=20)

DAOs will continue to grow and evolve out of their early experimental phases and into more mainstream adoption in coordinating groups with common aims and shared resources. Right now, the actions of setting up a DAO and programming it (through an absolute *launch* of beta tools) to accept member proposals, enable member votes, allocate funds, distribute shares, measure workload and contribution, track sentiment, manage communications, set up admission protocols, cultivate \*culture\*.  Rules so specific they can be interpreted by a machine, trying to play catch up to the ideas.

 
 My attempt to use (obey?) a discord bot to set up token distribution to digital wallets feels like moving too fast through a dark cave and then it feels like failure.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/0GBuY9UlCGr5to2w2-iMe.PNG?height=1334&width=750)

The DAO course was terrific, by the way, the best 20 HAUS tokens I have ever spent. 
  
 Some people have issues with DAOs because of their cypto-currency adjacency, because (currently) their primary use is to fuel group speculation on digital assets and (ideally) generate monthly salaries in hours for their members. To the extent that they solve problems, they’re mostly solving the problem that crypto created for itself. That will run its course and the philosophy and systems of decentralisation will morph as other goals find purpose and function within them. But now, at the beginning of the structuring of this system/s, we are talking about social benefits in a small echo chamber through the rigid language of code.  
  
 I told my boss at work about DAOs, but he hadn’t heard of a blockchain and the string between TradFi and DeFi was stretched too far. He said: *I hope they remember all of us old fashioned people in this future.* I agree, please don’t leave me behind, but on the other hand, TradFi never worried about those it excluded either.

DAOs have been described as *a discord with a shared bank account.* The majority are organised groups investing in digital assets. There was $10m in DAOs in 2019, and over $1B now. Beyond digital currency wealth, members talk a lot about how they value the community of a DAO. 

*Seeing Like a State* is a DAO reading list favourite because it describes repeating failures of centralised top-down organisations and by default seems to welcome the DAO fundamentals of decentralisation, transparency and coordination in decision-making, work, and reward.

But, by another reading of the text, it is the language and methods of measurement that have so effectively shaped the actions and outcomes Scott describes. Decentralised Autonomous Organisations do the same; instead of the metrics of natural resources the language is ***rules that a machine can understand.***

There is a schism between the language of DAOs and the language of the DAOists. Articulate, genius DAOist trailblazers carry me along on their belief that a better way of coordinating is possible and it’s here.

[https://twitter.com/owocki/status/1448016316523286529?s=20](https://twitter.com/owocki/status/1448016316523286529?s=20)

Ewoki GITER of COINS (Kevin Owocki of Github DAO) spoke to my class from Colorado, beautifully, astutely, fluidly. At one point he paused and reminded us: *Well, you know, there are a lot of other aspects grafted onto employment structures we need to consider, security, sick leave and health insurance, pension systems, unions. The old system has some benefits.*

The old system does have some benefits, although not for the globally connected 20-40 year old males who currently constitute the majority of the DAO community. We talk about this, too, the *problem of diversity*, the risk of a narrow group of people building the same infrastructure, following the same best practice applied across the board, with the same assumptions, the same solution to the same reading of the problem.

Even fluidly articulate Owocki shapes his compelling vision around the language of the technology that underpins it. Around tools, plug-ins, applications, perpetual rules that can’t be compromised, the ‘if then…’ clarity of the coder’s direction, the ability to fix scalability and coordination problems with clever technology.

[https://twitter.com/owocki/status/1448334880043982849?s=20](https://twitter.com/owocki/status/1448334880043982849?s=20)

DAOs will continue to grow and evolve out of their early experimental phases and into more mainstream adoption in coordinating groups with common aims and shared resources. Right now, the actions of setting up a DAO and programming it (through an absolute *launch* of beta tools) to accept member proposals, enable member votes, allocate funds, distribute shares, measure workload and contribution, track sentiment, manage communications, set up admission protocols, cultivate \*culture\*.  Rules so specific they can be interpreted by a machine, trying to play catch up to the ideas.

My attempt to use (obey?) a discord bot to set up token distribution to digital wallets feels like moving too fast through a dark cave and then it feels like failure.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/0GBuY9UlCGr5to2w2-iMe.PNG?height=1334&width=750)

The DAO course was terrific, by the way, the best 20 HAUS tokens I have ever spent.

Some people have issues with DAOs because of their cypto-currency adjacency, because (currently) their primary use is to fuel group speculation on digital assets and (ideally) generate monthly salaries in hours for their members. To the extent that they solve problems, they’re mostly solving the problem that crypto created for itself. That will run its course and the philosophy and systems of decentralisation will morph as other goals find purpose and function within them. But now, at the beginning of the structuring of this system/s, we are talking about social benefits in a small echo chamber through the rigid language of code.

I told my boss at work about DAOs, but he hadn’t heard of a blockchain and the string between TradFi and DeFi was stretched too far. He said: *I hope they remember all of us old fashioned people in this future.* I agree, please don’t leave me behind, but on the other hand, TradFi never worried about those it excluded either.

title: Seeing Like a Code: early interactions with DAOs
body:
### Creating new financial and governance systems is a political and social act, not a technocratic solution to an accepted problem, not a technical tool, although that’s where it starts.

*Seeing Like a State* by James C. Scott (1998) opens with the story of the invention of scientific forestry in 18th Century Prussia and Saxony. This is a model and a metaphor for the simplification and manipulation of the world by powerful institutions with sharply defined interests (such as nation states). In the case of forestry, the state’s tunnel vision is focused on resource extraction, translating the ancient forest into measurements of usable timber yield, and missing the other parts of the forest. Then, reshaping (clearing, ordering, replanting) forests to better suit measurement, administration and extraction of that resource. The ordered rows of single-species trees were, of course, catastrophic for the ecosystem.

*The instrument, the knife, that carved out the new, rudimentary forest was the razor-sharp interest in the production of a single commodity... Everything that seemed unrelated to efficient production was ignored. Having come to see the forest as a commodity, scientific forestry set about refashioning it as a commodity machine. (p.21)*

Top-down planning maps the world according to myopic short term interests. In Scott’s thesis this is the substrate to the tragic episodes of state development through the 20th Century, which combined the aspiration to the administrative ordering of nature and society, the use of power, and a weakened civil society lacking the capacity to resist.

It’s one of those non-fiction books where the author makes their claim and then delivers a regiment of chaptered illustrations in support. (Whisper: *This could have been an email*). I read it because it’s on the reading lists of many in the DAO community, and I’ve been doing a DAO course.

The world needs more larpers writing about DAOs like it needs a hole in the head. Except, such is the global network that the seeming cornucopia of discord servers bursting with DAO discourse represents people and ideas that are still in reality few and siloed.

title: yf2
body:
yfii复盘。2020-09-02 
 鉴于我在这个币上耗了很多的盯盘时间和紧张的精力，就复盘一下吧，提醒自己以后引以为戒。 
 在曹寅的群里看到曹寅推荐大家买yfii时，我就顺便买了一点。 
 （这是我的典型买币方式，信赖的大v推荐，就建仓。白皮书？创始人？投资方？nonono，都不需要的！这，很“韭菜”。） 
 这个操作是在钱包里进行的。后来我想，如果是在交易所买的，也许故事会不同，谁知道呢。 
 过了两天，我信赖的另一个v在社群里提醒，yfii是国内山寨分叉，警惕风险。 
 虽然我没啥操作，但这个提醒显然已经进入了我的潜意识。 
 又过了两天，有个大群里ceo发了一张图，里面总结了几个暴跌的defi币种，yfii赫然在列——曾经从800刀跌到现在的100多刀。 
 我也还是没什么操作，但这条消息也被我大脑记住了。 
 又过了几天，当我翻看买币软件时发现，其他币大部分都涨了，yfii还在跌，我已经浮亏1成多了。 
 我很烦躁。 
 恰巧那几天，曹寅也没在群里再说yfii了。也就是说，我脑中的负面消息占上风。 
 于是，我花了高额gas，在钱包里把yfii又换回eth。 
 过了仅仅两三天，yfii突然发车，翻倍，200刀。 
 我有点懵逼。有点损失厌恶。有点纠结。有点矛盾。 
 to追还是not to追？这是个问题。 
 追的话又是一笔高昂gas费。（其实也就一百块钱左右，现在想来，gas费算啥啊） 
 还是算了吧。不追。好马不吃回头草。 
 很快（一小时还是几小时还是一天我记不得了），yfii再次翻倍，400刀。 
 心好痛。 
 损失厌恶加重。 
 不追！ 
 第三天，1000刀。 
 操，“损失厌恶”四个字已经不足以形容我的痛苦了。 
 “损失憎恨”。 
 关于yfii，我试图不看不听不说。 
 然而，铺天盖地的yfii暴涨的消息，躲不过。——这像极了爱情：失恋，被甩，不想知道那个甩你的ta的消息，可是，偏偏，还是会知道。 
 尤其是曹寅大v已经开始大张旗鼓的宣传yfii了。社区海报喊单：目标8848刀。 
 我的心，很煎熬。 
 不断自责：如果我当初不割肉就好了…… 
 又过两天，随手看交易所软件行情，“不小心”又点到yfii里了。 
 我靠，已经1500刀了， 
 而且，就在我看的时候，明显还在拉盘（其实我对k线知之甚少，但那个不断突破新高的状态任谁都能看出来）。 
 我把持不住自己了，但理智在说：不能追高，不能追高。 
 感情说：追一点儿吧，一顿火锅钱呗。 
 于是，我在1900刀左右追了进去，买了一点点（对，我很节约）。 
 买了后我就没管，有一种夙愿完成的感觉。 
 身心突然好舒泰。 
 看什么都变得美好了。 
 第二天打开手机行情，傻了。 
 又翻了三倍。 
 昨天夜里最高到过5900刀。 
 现在还是5000多刀。 
 不但把之前亏的回本了，还多赚了。 
 我本来该高兴的。 
 但，我更痛苦了。 
 fomo模式启动。 
 我不停的问自己：为什么昨天不多买点儿？！ 
 再这么涨下去咋办？！ 
 我又开始自责了：如果当初多买点儿就好了。 
 那就等回调的时候赶紧加码吧？ 
 好，就这么办。 
 这时，其实已经有yfii的社区大v好心提醒：不要追高，再等等。 
 但我还是选择了在4700刀和3900刀分别接了两次。 
 回来的两天，价格一直在3000—3709刀震荡。共2500块。 
 我又开始着急了：怎么还不拉盘呢？ 
 （此时的我已经陷入了无脑韭菜模式，其实这时我应该暂时隔离整个币圈环境的） 
 于是，我又一次不耐烦了。 
 我把钱撤出来，先是换了yfi，后来又把yfi卖了还cvp。 
 只留了一点点。 
 如果故事到这里时，我能彻底消停下来，也算是不错的结局。 
 但是，我低估了自己的“搞砸力”。 
 昨天晚上，因为上架币安（我后来才知道），yfii经过两天多的盘整后再次飙车。 
 我本来应该坐在旁边开心看戏就好了。毕竟，我还是有一点点底仓啊（虽然很寒碜）。 
 但是作精如我，又来了一个神操作—— 
 我竟然在目睹拉盘的过程中对自己说“不如来个超超短线吧”。 
 于是，我竟然徒手接飞刀——高位买了。 
 那时是晚上七点多。 
 在我买后，盘面开始下跌。 
 （也可能我买的时候就变盘了，这 
 谁知道呢） 
 我一边洗碗一边盯盘。 
 半个小时内，看价格跌了又小涨又跌又涨，但始终涨不回我买的价位。 
 这时，娃在旁边催我，快点一起学英语。 
 算了算了，不盯了，割肉。 
 我把所有的yfii都卖了。 
 最后一算，亏了。 
 大脑有点空白。 
 心里还在想。 
 耗费了那么多心力，最后亏了。 
 哎… 
 八点多，我把碗刷完后，顺手看了眼其他的微信群。 
 看到有人说“一会儿不看拉那么猛”。 
 虽然那人的截图并未显示币种， 
 但我一看就知道那是yfii。 
 又开始拉了？ 
 再杀进去！ 
 此时的我已经杀红了眼。 
 用btc在0.53的点位换了一点。 
 我计算了一下，如果我7900刀挂单卖出，应该就能不赚不亏，回本。 
 于是我这么做了。 
 但是—— 
 （如果没有这个但是就好了） 
 我还是忍不住盯盘了。 
 只在给娃洗刷的20分钟里，没看盘。 
 结果发现，最高涨到过7400刀。 
 我自己洗澡的时候，看币价涨涨跌跌，大脑更乱了。 
 但没再上过7200刀。 
 怎么办？要不改挂7000刀吧？ 
 这时已经晚上十点半了。 
 娃催我睡觉睡觉。 
 我很烦躁：你自己先睡，别管我！ 
 最后娃在不开心的情绪中睡着了。 
 其他微信群里有人说“明天又会崩吧？” 
 我又忍不住了。 
 最后在6899刀的位置几乎出尽了。 
 只留了最后一点点yfii。 
 这么点儿，不可能指望它再有啥了。就是个纪念吧。毕竟，耗了我那么多时间、精力、情绪。 
 结算下来，还是亏了。 
 这最后的一点yfii像是个讽刺，又像是个提醒：别再做韭菜了

title: 碎片
body:
20200902 
 微博v 何太极说，本金小的情况下，分散持仓不如重仓一个，有利于做大本金，并说，50w rmb以下就是小本金这么看来，我真的不用玩币了。 
 最近牛市初期，各种暴富消息又频频传来。可是我还在耗心耗力的奋斗中——亏损。 
 也是没谁了 
 记得上一轮17年的时候也是这样，但当时我刚进币圈，懵懵懂懂，只是看热闹，并由谨小慎微到头脑发热到做接盘侠… 
 本来以为到这一轮牛市我会好一些，可是最近两天我耗在yfii上的荒谬行径又让我依稀看到了2017-2018时的那个自己。 
 说到底，财不进急门。 
 那些稳定赚到不少钱的，是数学好、心态稳的人。 
 这些素质，一半是先天（遗传），一半是后天（锻炼身体、打坐…）。 
 没关系，赚适合自己的钱。 
 就算赚到了贝塔也是很好的呀。 
 关键是探索适合自己的和不适合自己的投资或者说生活方式。 
 我还是坚信，属于我的赚钱方式应该是不费力的、快乐的、滋养我的。

20200830

本金的体量决定心态。 
 别人拿1w买个币随便玩玩，我拿1w就紧张的睡不着觉，这还咋尝试新鲜事物嘛？ 
 所以目前还是用小零钱积累经验的阶段。 
 yfii得到的教训： 
 1）买一个标的之前一定要对它有最起码的了解； 
 2）无知割肉后，如果了解增多，那么就不要被损失厌恶的情绪控制，而要及时再上车。

20200823

最近几天一直因为自己错失一个疯狂涨的币而低气压， 
 虽然有股票投资经验的小伙伴提醒我不要因为一点儿得失而苛责自己， 
 但还是会忍不住懊悔，并试图做鸵鸟：取关、不看微信群消息，它再涨多少与我无关…… 
 理智上知道，这样是不对的。 
 但心里实在接受不了。 
 大v们说，投资（机）是考验人性的， 
 这个人性指的是什么？贪，嗔，痴… 
 “炒币”的人就是容易陷在这些里。 
 所以，这其实也是一场很好的修行对不对。 
 所以，请慢慢平复心境，这本来就是个交学费、找厉炼的过程。 
 这也是个很好的认清自己的机会， 
 知道自己是中等资质， 
 就不要企图做那种低买高卖的操作， 
 安下心来， 
 不断学习积累知识、资料、成绩（以及，薪水）， 
 尽可能用自己的脑子筛选出自己中意的标的， 
 然后，熊市布局，牛市收获， 
 就像耕种，顺应天时，春种秋收。 
 这是普通人的平稳、平静、乏味的投资练习之路。 
 不，其实能做到这些，已经不普通了。 
 加油

20200812

今天夜里又失眠了。 
 半夜醒了。 
 于是就开始想这两天的炒币经历。 
 想那些被自己踏空的币，本来都预设好的操作，没有执行下去，临时起意卖掉了。 
 当然，我本金很少，所以即使卖早了也损失不了多少钱。 
 而且，富贵在天。 
 我其实不用那么焦虑的。 
 不知道为啥，就是一直心浮气躁的感觉。 
 觉得自己数学太差，又不喜欢独立思考，不适合炒币。 
 安心定投比特币，吃beta收益，其实不也挺香的吗？ 
 哎… 
 还有我之前重仓的KEY。今年生日时我还花钱加仓到1kw枚整。可是，看着其他币都涨，只有KEY在不停的跌的时候，我才明白了钢铁侠为什么说“KEY是好资产，但现在时机还未到”。可能因为他计算了KEY的每日增发，从而与一些羊毛写手的抛压联系起来，从而得出的结论吧。 
 我今天夜里决定把KEY全部解锁，换成比特币。 
 同时，决定安心翻译，在币乎上发文。

20200802

说说我最近两天的感受吧：一脸懵逼，每天看着钱包里的浮盈涨一点，但却不敢动，因为刚处于回本边缘，怕动了以后后悔 ​​​

短线也不敢炒，因为都涨过了，不知道该买哪个了，怕跌 ​​​

我还是坚信，属于我的赚钱方式应该是不费力的、快乐的、滋养我的。

20200830

本金的体量决定心态。
别人拿1w买个币随便玩玩，我拿1w就紧张的睡不着觉，这还咋尝试新鲜事物嘛？
所以目前还是用小零钱积累经验的阶段。
yfii得到的教训：
1）买一个标的之前一定要对它有最起码的了解；
2）无知割肉后，如果了解增多，那么就不要被损失厌恶的情绪控制，而要及时再上车。

20200823

最近几天一直因为自己错失一个疯狂涨的币而低气压，
虽然有股票投资经验的小伙伴提醒我不要因为一点儿得失而苛责自己，
但还是会忍不住懊悔，并试图做鸵鸟：取关、不看微信群消息，它再涨多少与我无关……
理智上知道，这样是不对的。
但心里实在接受不了。
大v们说，投资（机）是考验人性的，
这个人性指的是什么？贪，嗔，痴…
“炒币”的人就是容易陷在这些里。
所以，这其实也是一场很好的修行对不对。
所以，请慢慢平复心境，这本来就是个交学费、找厉炼的过程。
这也是个很好的认清自己的机会，
知道自己是中等资质，
就不要企图做那种低买高卖的操作，
安下心来，
不断学习积累知识、资料、成绩（以及，薪水），
尽可能用自己的脑子筛选出自己中意的标的，
然后，熊市布局，牛市收获，
就像耕种，顺应天时，春种秋收。
这是普通人的平稳、平静、乏味的投资练习之路。
不，其实能做到这些，已经不普通了。
加油

20200812

今天夜里又失眠了。
半夜醒了。
于是就开始想这两天的炒币经历。
想那些被自己踏空的币，本来都预设好的操作，没有执行下去，临时起意卖掉了。
当然，我本金很少，所以即使卖早了也损失不了多少钱。
而且，富贵在天。
我其实不用那么焦虑的。
不知道为啥，就是一直心浮气躁的感觉。
觉得自己数学太差，又不喜欢独立思考，不适合炒币。
安心定投比特币，吃beta收益，其实不也挺香的吗？
哎…
还有我之前重仓的KEY。今年生日时我还花钱加仓到1kw枚整。可是，看着其他币都涨，只有KEY在不停的跌的时候，我才明白了钢铁侠为什么说“KEY是好资产，但现在时机还未到”。可能因为他计算了KEY的每日增发，从而与一些羊毛写手的抛压联系起来，从而得出的结论吧。
我今天夜里决定把KEY全部解锁，换成比特币。
同时，决定安心翻译，在币乎上发文。

20200802

说说我最近两天的感受吧：一脸懵逼，每天看着钱包里的浮盈涨一点，但却不敢动，因为刚处于回本边缘，怕动了以后后悔 ​​​

短线也不敢炒，因为都涨过了，不知道该买哪个了，怕跌 ​​​

20200524

记得曾做过武志红公号推送的一个心理测试，结果是，我是个“人生体验者”，看了这个说法我特么笑了，这个心理测试设计者也太会造词了，其实你直言“混子”岂不更耿直？ 
 bihu两周年时也有个小游戏，我的年度关键词是“撸神”特么钱包里一堆归零币，这个称号我着实受之有愧啊 ​​​

20200519

凑齐1kw的bihu 的key，不知道会不会归零 ​​​。

20200507

蛮悲哀的，活了三十多年，感觉没有自己擅长的。 
  
 没有读多少书，没有什么经验。我这些年都是怎么过来的？除了自卑和偶尔自负，还能给自己什么评价？ 
  
 这也是我想涉足“区块链”行业的原因，因为这是个还算新的行业。可是进来后发现，无非是换个叫法而已，其实做事情的方式还是不变的。 
  
 所以，锻炼好一些基本技能才是关键。

title: Mango integration, localnet testing and Anchor CPI to non Anchor programs
body:
So lately I’ve been tasked to integrate the Solana Program I’m working on with Mango.
I want to gather the knowledge and tidbits that I find valuable in case that can be of use.

*Sky Burial #2 by Wayne Haag, because space derelicts stuff look cool*


______

Mango is a decentralised exchange (DEX) that offer leveraged trading and perpetuals.

Mango is managed by a DAO and seems like a great functional example of decentralised governance.

And most importantly, it’s a neat product I use since months, my main DEX. Neat features and UI, smooth UX.


_____

## Localnet dev environment with --clone

In order to be productive, I want to iterate quickly.

Mango is currently accessible on `devnet` and `main-net` clusters, but my anchor workspace contains several projects, that I modify often, so I don’t feel like using `devnet`.

I want to be able to have my usual `anchor test` speed, not sure what happen behind the curtain but the deployments to `localnet` don’t event appear in the prompt, making it ideal for iterating fast.

In order to use Mango on `localnet` I found this neat option for `solana-test-validator` (the program running `localnet` coming with the Solana cli) :

`--clone <account>`  (credits to dvcrn#7961 on the Anchor discord)

It copies accounts from another cluster into the starting `localnet` instance, and note that once you run the `solana-local-validator` once, it create a `test-ledger` folder that store its state. So `--clone` only have effect when this `test-ledger` is not there, of if you use `--reset` to start fresh.

This is how I use it :

```
#!/bin/bash

# Reset then configure the local validator to mimic the mango accounts on devnet
solana-test-validator \
 --reset                                                `: # Reset the test-ledger` \
 --url https://mango.devnet.rpcpool.com                 `: # Cluster from which the below program will be cloned` \
 --clone TokenkegQfeZyiNwAJbNbGKPFXCWuBvf9Ss623VQ5DA    `: # token program` \
 --clone ATokenGPvbdGVxr1b2hvZbsiqW5xWH25efTNsLJA8knL   `: # assoc token program` \
 --clone aca3VWxwBeu8FTZowJ9hfSKGzntjX68EXh1N9xpE1PC    `: # Acam wallet` \
 --clone 9KBGW5bbfdLA4zKAXPETwjR5Ub7BR2Zh9gKHsPnrUkUg   `: ## BTC assoc token acc` \
 --clone 7CZfVDqqYueBujgvqxwDp7Y29eoe5zcgdcqvsUW5bcqP   `: ## USDC assoc token acc` \
 --clone 4uv1EwgZNa91tnBbr49KrQmpb29mp95e9ATh77tgxr6B   `: ## WSOL assoc token acc` \
 --clone Eyh77zP5b7arPtPgpnCT8vsGmq9p5Z9HHnBSeQLnAFQi   `: # Test user wallet` \
 --clone C2CmwB1DBgaKUKHUNi9Ua55wKSH12W95wJEe8yMbSzCN   `: ## BTC assoc token acc` \
 --clone gq25cMCGNb9VNquJsqTYNpipUjZbVB6FktQiENvnq7q    `: ## USDC assoc token acc` \
 --clone 92jBUBivpzTu5EEtdVgKXXwmEhfqFMsg91z2RRYyobFQ   `: ## WSOL assoc token acc` \
 --clone 8FRFC6MoGGkMFQwngccyu69VnYbzykGeez7ignHVAFSN   `: # USDC mango test TOKEN MINT followed by mango root/node` \
 --clone HUBX4iwWEUK5VrXXXcB7uhuKrfT4fpu2T9iZbg712JrN \
 --clone J2Lmnc1e4frMnBEJARPoHtfpcohLfN67HdK1inXjTFSM \
 --clone 3UNBZ6o52WTWwjac2kPUb4FyodhU1vFkRJheu1Sh2TvU   `: # BTC TOKEN MINT followed by mango root/node`\
 --clone BeEoyDq1v2DYJCoXDQAJKfmrsoRRvfmV856f2ijkXbtp \
 --clone 4X3nP921qyh6BKJSAohKGNCykSXahFFwg1LxtC993Fai \
 --clone Bb9bsTQa1bGEtQ5KagGkvSHyuLqDWumFUcRqFusFNJWC   `: # Mango TOKEN MINT followed by mango root/node` \
 --clone CY4nMV9huW5KCYFxWChrmoLwGCsZiXoiREeo2PMrBm5o \
 --clone 6rkPNJTXF37X6Pf5ct5Y6E91PozpZpZNNU1AGATomKjD \
 --clone So11111111111111111111111111111111111111112    `: # WSOL TOKEN MINT followed by mango root/node` \
 --clone 8GC81raaLjhTx3yedctxCJW46qdmmSRybH2s1eFYFFxT \
 --clone 7mYqCavd1K24fnL3oKTpX3YM66W5gfikmVHJWM3nrWKe \
 --clone Ec2enZyoC4nGpEfu2sUNAa2nUGJHWxoUWYSEJ2hNTWTA   `: # MANGO starts - devnet.2 cluster `\
 --clone 4skJ85cdxQAFVKbcGgfun8iZPL7BadVYXG3kGEGkufqA   `: # mangoProgramId `\
 --clone 6eadH6vSsEk5bPiXWPYRq5KRSjohfYd6Ug5HjGbxaWce \
 --clone DESVgJVGajEgKGXhb6XmqDHGz3VjdgP7rEVESBgxmroY   `: # serumProgramId`\
 --clone AvKzLiE8ezzp6kLVw49nq8drycE89NS1RQaBWjBNeUoF \
 --clone HovQMDrbAgAYPCmHVSrezcSmkMtXSSUsLDFANExrZh2J   `: # BTC oracle `\
 --clone J83w4HKfqxwcq3BEMMkPFSppX3gqekLyLJBexebFVkix   `: # SOL oracle `\
 --clone 8k7F9Xb36oFJsjpCKpsXvg4cgBRoZtwNTc3EzG5Ttd2o   `: # MNGO oracle `\
 --clone FHQtNjRHA9U5ahrH7mWky3gamouhesyQ5QvpeGKrTh2z   `: # BTC Perp market `\
 --clone F1Dcnq6F8NXR3gXADdsYqrXYBUUwoT7pfCtRuQWSyQFd   `: ## bidsKey `\
 --clone BFEBZsLYmEhj4quWDRKbyMKhW1Q9c7gu3LqsnipNGTVn   `: ## asksKey `\
 --clone Bu17U2YdBM9gRrqQ1zD6MpngQBb71RRAAn8dbxoFDSkU   `: ## eventsKey `\
 --clone 58vac8i9QXStG1hpaa4ouwE1X7ngeDjY9oY7R15hcbKJ   `: # SOL Perp market `\
 --clone 7HRgm8iXEDx2TmSETo3Lq9SXkF954HMVKNiq8t5sKvQS   `: ## bidsKey `\
 --clone 4oNxXQv1Rx3h7aNWjhTs3PWBoXdoPZjCaikSThV4yGb8   `: ## asksKey `\
 --clone CZ5MCRvkN38d5pnZDDEEyMiED3drgDUVpEUjkuJq31Kf   `: ## eventsKey `
#  > /dev/null 2>&1 &
```

I run that script once to configure my `localnet`, or to reset it.

You can then start you `solana-local-validator` the usual way, or run the above script each time if you want to have a deterministic environment.

You then call `anchor test --skip-local-validator` to ran your test suit against it (at first I though Anchor would pick up the local `test-ledger` but it doesn’t)

All the accounts come from the mango `ids.rs`

[https://github.com/blockworks-foundation/mango-client-v3/blob/main/src/ids.json](https://github.com/blockworks-foundation/mango-client-v3/blob/main/src/ids.json)


______

One neat thing that you might have caught in the above script, is that to also copy my users accounts and their associated token accounts from the devnet in order to have the right tokens and balances, mints and identities without bothering with mocking :

```
// ...
--clone aca3VWxwBeu8FTZowJ9hfSKGzntjX68EXh1N9xpE1PC    `: # Acam wallet` \
 --clone 9KBGW5bbfdLA4zKAXPETwjR5Ub7BR2Zh9gKHsPnrUkUg   `: ## BTC assoc token acc` \
 --clone 7CZfVDqqYueBujgvqxwDp7Y29eoe5zcgdcqvsUW5bcqP   `: ## USDC assoc token acc` \
 --clone 4uv1EwgZNa91tnBbr49KrQmpb29mp95e9ATh77tgxr6B   `: ## WSOL assoc token acc` \
 --clone Eyh77zP5b7arPtPgpnCT8vsGmq9p5Z9HHnBSeQLnAFQi   `: # Test user wallet` \
 --clone C2CmwB1DBgaKUKHUNi9Ua55wKSH12W95wJEe8yMbSzCN   `: ## BTC assoc token acc` \
 --clone gq25cMCGNb9VNquJsqTYNpipUjZbVB6FktQiENvnq7q    `: ## USDC assoc token acc` \
 --clone 92jBUBivpzTu5EEtdVgKXXwmEhfqFMsg91z2RRYyobFQ   `: ## WSOL assoc token acc` \
// ...
```

You can easily follow Mango tutorial to get Devnet tokens, then go trade these on the devnet Mango for other Sol, BTC and the like (That’s a good way to avoid the devnet sol airdrop limitation 🤫)

[https://docs.mango.markets/tutorials/how-to-receive-dev-net-tokens](https://docs.mango.markets/tutorials/how-to-receive-dev-net-tokens)

All in all, this allows me to send Mango instructions like `InitMangoAccount` successfully.

One last thing that I loose using `anchor test --skip-local-validator` compared to just running `anchor test` is that the deployment does prompt now, not as fast. Will look into that later to understand what’s the diff.


__________

## Anchor and CPI to Mango

Mango is not Anchor friendly, seems normal as the project is big and complex, and has been started from before Anchor. Also they probably don’t want to rely on a WIP framework.

Most of the “issues” here, are not really issues… Just sugar and QoL stuff, subjective.

First issues is that you cannot use the idiomatic Anchor stuff like `Program<‘info, Mango>` as mango did not have a declare_id required by Anchor.

Did a smol PR about it :

[https://github.com/blockworks-foundation/mango-v3/pull/67](https://github.com/blockworks-foundation/mango-v3/pull/67)


_____

### Creating and initialising the MangoAccount

The next thing is that the `mango::state::MangoAccount` has a span of 28912 bytes if I’m not mistaken, preventing you to use the Anchor IDL account creation :

```
    #[account(
        init,
        seeds = [MANGO_SEED, mint.key().as_ref()],
        bump,
        payer = authority,
        owner = mango::mango_program::Mango::id(), // This is my custom stuff added with the PR above
        space = MANGO_ACCOUNT_SPAN, // 28912
    )]
    pub mango_account: AccountInfo<'info>,
```

Results in this error :
`Account data size realloc limited to 10240 in inner instructions`

So I fall back on the associated instruction init as follows :

```
// ... In the Solana program
// signer cause it's required later for the CPI initialization 
#[account(mut, signer)]
pub mango_account: AccountInfo<'info>,
// ...
```

and in the typescript code

```
// ...
   const mangoAccount = new Keypair(); 
   const createMangoAccountIx = SystemProgram.createAccount({
      programId: MANGO_PROGRAM_ID,
      space: MangoAccountLayout.span,
      lamports: await getRentExemption(MangoAccountLayout.span),
      fromPubkey: admin.wallet.publicKey,
      newAccountPubkey: mangoAccount.publicKey, 
    });
    // Then call your program instruction and don't forget the IX + the mangoAccount.secretKey in the signers.
    // instructions: [createMangoAccountIx],
    // signers: [mangoAccount.secretKey],
// ...
```


_____

### Mint-erlude 🥂

For the next “Mango related” part, I will have to stop testing with my locally crafted mints, and start using the actual `devnet` token mints, so that the cloned accounts from the mango program can find their babies.

Here I go on `devnet` , I create a new wallet, fund it with some of the required tokens.

![r i c h](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/C7r_Z4yLnUpTe4oVh9cB3.png?height=352&width=1978)

Next step is to go in the script that setup the local environment for `localnet` and add this new account to the cloning.

```
// ...
--clone Eyh77zP5b7arPtPgpnCT8vsGmq9p5Z9HHnBSeQLnAFQi   `: # Test user wallet` \
// ...
```

Final step, is to go in the program and create the `Keypair` associated to these thanks to the exported Private Key. (We need keypair to sign stuff)

```
// ...
// aca3VWxwBeu8FTZowJ9hfSKGzntjX68EXh1N9xpE1PC
const aca3VWSeed = Uint8Array.from([
  197, 246, ... 146, 223,
]);
// Eyh77zP5b7arPtPgpnCT8vsGmq9p5Z9HHnBSeQLnAFQi
const Eyh77Seed = Uint8Array.from([
  219, 139, ... 212, 175,
]);

// Identities - both of these are wallets that exists on devnet, we clone them in the localnet env
aca3VWxwBeu8FTZowJ9hfSKGzntjX68EXh1N9xpE1PC
export let admin = Keypair.fromSecretKey(aca3VWSeed);
export let user = Keypair.fromSecretKey(Eyh77Seed);
// ...
```

Now I have my test identities that are funded and ready to be used.


_____

### Depositing to the Mango Account

I’ll update this article with the next part as I advance.

title: G.A.T.E. — Goals|Action|Track| Embrace — An Approach Shared by a Tired Mind.
body:
# The Power of Our Minds

When you have faith in the extraordinary power of your mind, the mind tends to acknowledge that and offer you a lot in return.

It's a relationship. You have to have faith in each other to yield the optimum results from this relationship.

Through the past few years, the habit of reading, writing, meditation, and outdoor running has helped me build an exceptional habit — **Listening to my mind.**

And, that in turn has helped me invest and have more faith in our relationship.

# Be Better Bit-By-Bit

"Be Better Bit-By-Bit" is an endeavor through which I aim to build a fresh perspective towards Self-Improvement.

Time and again, I have sensed that **"It's not for me"** is the common perception when it comes to "Self-improvement."

And that's the gap I am trying to fill — To make "self-improvement" a core part of your life. Everyone's life.

As part of the effort, we recently had a **"Three Challenges Challenge**." A seven days challenge that expected the participants to challenge themselves on three fronts:

* No added sugar — avoid as much "added" sugar,
* Hydration — A minimum of ten glasses of water during the day, and
* Five different fruits each day.

Consistently, over a long period, the platform's agenda is to keep the goals and efforts small — but consistent.

## The approach:

* Firstly, accept and declare your participation in the goal/challenge — Written agreement is an indication to the "chimp" mind that you are ready, and hence he needs to be ready too.
* The next step is to build necessary modifications in the schedule — identify and bring small sub-goals and actions, and
* Finally, track your progress in a structured manner.

**The final element is essential** — the belief is that a goal or a habit picks up the right pace when we track it well. Else, it will fall into gaps.

# An Odd Time and an Odd Suggestion

Though self-improvement attracts a lot of initial excitement, the experience has taught me that this excitement doesn't last long. So it's essential to keep the audience engaged at all times.

After three days of enthusiasm, I searched for the next nudge and a "change in perspective" content.

It was essential to keep the fire alive in everyone's belly.

As I was approaching bedtime at the end of the fourth day, the idea kept hitting me. My body was exhausted, and I was crying to lie down in the bed. Still, the idea kept nagging me.

* **What can I share with them?**
* **How can I push them to track their goals consistently?**

That's when my sleeping mind came up with an acronym — **G.A.T.E**.

But, the tired mind was battling to remember the acronym; it was dying to sleep.

And, it did.

The acronym did not register well in mind.

# The Recall

As I woke up the next day, I did not remember the acronym at all. The morning routine started as usual. I was soon ready for the outdoor run and entered the dark lanes around my home. As I took the first few steps, the morning mind brought back the acronym — **G.A.T.E**.

A connection soon got established, and my mind helped me recall the individual elements of the acronym.

**G — Goals** — Set measurable goals/sub-goals.

**A — Action** — Take appropriate small actions.

**T — Track** — Track your progress against the measure.

**E — Embrace** — Embrace, enjoy and be consistent with the change.

# Habit and Goal Building — Acronyms in Use

Many [authors and personalities](https://boardview.io/blog/goal-setting-acronyms-three-attributes-common/) have shared their views using different acronyms related to habit or goal building:

* [SMART ](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SMART_criteria)— Specific, Measurable, Attainable/Achievable, Realistic, Time-Bound
* CLEAR — Collaborative, Limited, Emotional, Appreciable, Refinable — Shared by Adam Kreek.
* **[ACTION](http://7rulesofachievement.com/achievement/action-goals-criteria-goal-setting-worksheet/)** by Tom Terwilliger: Accessible, Clearly Stated and Concise, Towards and Timed, Impassioned, Organic, As if Now
* **[QUEST](https://books.google.nl/books?id=6Uevrxv6A8YC&pg=PA94&lpg=PA94&)** by W. Timothy Gallwey about set learning goals — Qualities, Understanding, Expertise, Strategic thinking, Time
* **[PRAGMATIC](http://www.aic.gov.au/media_library/conferences/evaluation/williams.pdf)** mentioned by Paul Williams: Proximate, Relevant, reliable, reportable, Achievable, Game-proof, Measurable, Appropriate, Timely, Time-based, Integrated, Cost-effective

These acronyms help us set a context and follow a method while deciding and approaching a goal.

I believe that if an idea is genuine, it will come back to me. And that's why the **G.A.T.E.** acronym decided to come back in those early morning hours and became my version of habit and goal building.

# G.A.T.E. Approach Explained

Fear and self-doubt are some of the most critical things impacting self-growth.

And, that's why I recognize the approach of small and consistent improvements.

**G.A.T.E. is a sub-approach to the overall philosophy of "Be Better Bit-By-Bit."**

**G**oals — Set measurable goals and sub-goals.

Set goals. And then set a measure to it. Drinking ten glasses of water, eating five fruits a day — are small measurable goals towards the larger goals, i.e., Weight management.

If you don't know what you want, then you don't know what to do. And, if you don't know the sub-goals, you don't know what to do next.

**A**ction — Take appropriate small actions.

Once you have the goals/sub-goals, convert them into meaningful actions. Og Mandino says in his famous book — *"No planning can replace the actual actions."*

Breaking down actions is important after identifying the sub-goals because small actions help you maintain consistent behavior.

**T**rack — Track your progress.

Relying on willpower generally fails us in the long term. There are times when it is difficult to manage consistency even after doing everything right.

An efficient tracking mechanism helps you create an awareness of your progress. And then the goal moves on an auto-trajectory.

* How do I know I am managing my weight loss journey well without recording the workouts and their impact on the weight?
* How do I know my TIME spent if I don't track the TIME consumption?
* How can I complete the manuscript of my next book if I don't set a daily target and track the word count?
* How can we manage our financial goals if we don't track the investments and the returns?

**E**mbrace — Embrace and enjoy and be consistent with the change.

**Be Better Bit-By-Bit = Small + Consistent Actions.**

Consistency is as important as breaking down the goals into the sub and measurable goals.

Once these two elements enter your life, the goals and habits embrace you. In return, you need to embrace and celebrate them each day.

# Conclusion

**G.A.T.E.** might not be a holistic approach to habit building, but to me, it's a good indicator of the four essential components that can help build a sustained habit.

**G.A.T.E.** is a gift offered to me by my mind because I opted to put enough faith in the ideas shared by him.

The habit formation strategy need not be extra brilliant, nor do they require incredible willpower, dedication, or time. Instead, by starting small, extra-ordinarily small, you can gradually work up to the habit you're trying to build.

You need knowledge of how habits work and your behavior to implement a strategy like **G.A.T.E.** effectively.

**G.A.T.E.** works for me, and hopefully, the information and perspective I am trying to outline will help set you up for success.

**If I can do this, anyone can do this.**

\-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Nishith is an author and creator of a unique self-development platform — **"Be Better Bit-By-Bit."**

Grab your copy of his debut book — [Be Better Bit-By-Bit](https://www.amazon.in/dp/9387004295/ref=cm_sw_r_wa_apa_i_Nh.aGb972P6ZJ) and listen to his podcasts [Be Better Bit-By-Bit](https://open.spotify.com/show/0pum5rJmbp1PkWYIwOjFfz?si=8lMjcvG1SzGyzrhOvlCNfQ) and [10 Bullets — 100 Words Book Summary](https://open.spotify.com/show/5LWIrRkURIV5Sh3GGXfSs6?si=PVzFilPKShS1jPHDi5rD-Q).

title: World gets different in every second
body:
Yesterday I’ve heard the sad news that someone I knew had passed away. What’s being worse is that the person had decided to end life, leaving family with three young kids behind.

Aside of the very tragedy itself, which had brought great pain and sadness to the close ones, one thing that came to my mind is a reminder of how the world can change in any second and we cannot do anything about it.

When it does, and it does for the worse, we often regret not doing more, not enjoying more of the past world, which is now the thing of the past. And while we know that such abrupt changes will inevitably comes to us and our families as well (and they will be always here much sooner, as there is not such thing as the right timing), we do not act on this. We carry on like nothing happens.

In Bhutan, one of the happiest countries in the world, people are aiming to contemplate on death five times a day. (and for us everywhere else, [there’s an app for that](https://www.wecroak.com/)) There’s nothing in the world which can prepare you for the situation such as I’ve described at the beginning of this post. But while hopefully you won’t be facing such tragedy, some flavour of it will come sooner of later.

And while we won’t be able to do anything about it and it will hurt, we at least should have known that we've enjoyed the time before - when the world had been a different place.

title: 币圈的FOMO日记
body:
今天也是平凡的一天，睡醒起来打开行情软件看看自己买的币是涨是跌，然后去收一下菜，挖提卖搞掉了。

接着就是打开微信，看看那几个炒币群，果不其然还是有接近上千条消息未读，卧了个槽，你们都不睡觉在搞钱的吗？！想想自己竟然能睡觉，我真TM懒惰啊，要改要改！

进了币圈之后，如果心态不好真的非常容易崩，我不知道大家有没有这种感觉，反正我是挺深体会的。

## 微信群聊

很多时候我们都会加很多微信的社群，有分享资讯的，有跟着大V学习的，里面的群友都非常牛逼，你甚至都无法想象他们一天能赚多少钱，当然我相信这只是少部分优秀的人，因为想我这种没赚到多少的就只是偶尔冒一下泡而已。

看着群友们动辄一天就赚几万来块，有时候除了羡慕就是羡慕，对，就是光看着群友赚钱，难受！有句话不是这么说的么：看到你赚钱比我自己亏钱还要难受。虽然心里知道这种心态要不得，但是就是控制不住。。

另外，资讯爆炸的话也会让人产生FOMO。

* 撸空投别人做了，你没有做的fomo
* 任务太多，自己做不完又怕错过的fomo
* 项目太多看不完的fomo

## 摆正心态

说真的，币圈不缺机会，反而是机会太多了，多得让你自己眼花缭乱，从而迷失掉自己。

一会儿群里冒出个人说买这个币，一会儿又说那个币是机会，一会儿又说得去哪里撸个空投。那你不得累死，被人牵着鼻子来走。

在币圈，你要找到那个属于你自己的机会，然后下重注，才有机会慢慢积累到自己的财富，不要怕时间长，要明白一个真理，慢就是快！很多人都知道，但就是很难控制好自己，导致自己的动作变形。其实我自己也是一样，写下来也是在提醒我自己而已。

先写到这里，还没摸清Mirror怎么玩，后期再多一点更新！

title: Mango integration, localnet testing and Anchor CPI to non Anchor programs
body:
So lately I’ve been tasked to integrate the Solana Program I’m working on with Mango.
I want to gather the knowledge and tidbits that I find valuable in case that can be of use.

*Sky Burial #2 by Wayne Haag, because space derelicts stuff look cool*


______

Mango is a decentralised exchange (DEX) that offer leveraged trading and perpetuals.

Mango is managed by a DAO and seems like a great functional example of decentralised governance.

And most importantly, it’s a neat product I use since months, my main DEX. Neat features and UI, smooth UX.


_____

## Localnet dev environment with --clone

In order to be productive, I want to iterate quickly.

Mango is currently accessible on `devnet` and `main-net` clusters, but my anchor workspace contains several projects, that I modify often, so I don’t feel like using `devnet`.

I want to be able to have my usual `anchor test` speed, not sure what happen behind the curtain but the deployments to `localnet` don’t event appear in the prompt, making it ideal for iterating fast.

In order to use Mango on `localnet` I found this neat option for `solana-test-validator` (the program running `localnet` coming with the Solana cli) :

`--clone <account>`  (credits to dvcrn#7961 on the Anchor discord)

It copies accounts from another cluster into the starting `localnet` instance, and note that once you run the `solana-local-validator` once, it create a `test-ledger` folder that store its state. So `--clone` only have effect when this `test-ledger` is not there, of if you use `--reset` to start fresh.

This is how I use it :

```
#!/bin/bash

# Reset then configure the local validator to mimic the mango accounts on devnet
solana-test-validator \
 --reset                                                `: # Reset the test-ledger` \
 --url https://mango.devnet.rpcpool.com                 `: # Cluster from which the below program will be cloned` \
 --clone TokenkegQfeZyiNwAJbNbGKPFXCWuBvf9Ss623VQ5DA    `: # token program` \
 --clone ATokenGPvbdGVxr1b2hvZbsiqW5xWH25efTNsLJA8knL   `: # assoc token program` \
 --clone aca3VWxwBeu8FTZowJ9hfSKGzntjX68EXh1N9xpE1PC    `: # Acam wallet` \
 --clone 9KBGW5bbfdLA4zKAXPETwjR5Ub7BR2Zh9gKHsPnrUkUg   `: ## BTC assoc token acc` \
 --clone 7CZfVDqqYueBujgvqxwDp7Y29eoe5zcgdcqvsUW5bcqP   `: ## USDC assoc token acc` \
 --clone Eyh77zP5b7arPtPgpnCT8vsGmq9p5Z9HHnBSeQLnAFQi   `: # Test user wallet` \
 --clone C2CmwB1DBgaKUKHUNi9Ua55wKSH12W95wJEe8yMbSzCN   `: ## BTC assoc token acc` \
 --clone gq25cMCGNb9VNquJsqTYNpipUjZbVB6FktQiENvnq7q    `: ## USDC assoc token acc` \
 --clone 8FRFC6MoGGkMFQwngccyu69VnYbzykGeez7ignHVAFSN   `: # USDC mango test TOKEN MINT followed by mango root/node` \
 --clone HUBX4iwWEUK5VrXXXcB7uhuKrfT4fpu2T9iZbg712JrN \
 --clone J2Lmnc1e4frMnBEJARPoHtfpcohLfN67HdK1inXjTFSM \
 --clone 3UNBZ6o52WTWwjac2kPUb4FyodhU1vFkRJheu1Sh2TvU   `: # BTC TOKEN MINT followed by mango root/node`\
 --clone BeEoyDq1v2DYJCoXDQAJKfmrsoRRvfmV856f2ijkXbtp \
 --clone 4X3nP921qyh6BKJSAohKGNCykSXahFFwg1LxtC993Fai \
 --clone Bb9bsTQa1bGEtQ5KagGkvSHyuLqDWumFUcRqFusFNJWC   `: # Mango TOKEN MINT followed by mango root/node` \
 --clone CY4nMV9huW5KCYFxWChrmoLwGCsZiXoiREeo2PMrBm5o \
 --clone 6rkPNJTXF37X6Pf5ct5Y6E91PozpZpZNNU1AGATomKjD \
 --clone So11111111111111111111111111111111111111112    `: # WSOL TOKEN MINT followed by mango root/node` \
 --clone 8GC81raaLjhTx3yedctxCJW46qdmmSRybH2s1eFYFFxT \
 --clone 7mYqCavd1K24fnL3oKTpX3YM66W5gfikmVHJWM3nrWKe \
 --clone Ec2enZyoC4nGpEfu2sUNAa2nUGJHWxoUWYSEJ2hNTWTA   `: # MANGO starts - devnet.2 cluster `\
 --clone 4skJ85cdxQAFVKbcGgfun8iZPL7BadVYXG3kGEGkufqA   `: # mangoProgramId `\
 --clone 6eadH6vSsEk5bPiXWPYRq5KRSjohfYd6Ug5HjGbxaWce \
 --clone DESVgJVGajEgKGXhb6XmqDHGz3VjdgP7rEVESBgxmroY   `: # serumProgramId`\
 --clone AvKzLiE8ezzp6kLVw49nq8drycE89NS1RQaBWjBNeUoF \
 --clone HovQMDrbAgAYPCmHVSrezcSmkMtXSSUsLDFANExrZh2J   `: # BTC oracle `\
 --clone J83w4HKfqxwcq3BEMMkPFSppX3gqekLyLJBexebFVkix   `: # SOL oracle `\
 --clone 8k7F9Xb36oFJsjpCKpsXvg4cgBRoZtwNTc3EzG5Ttd2o   `: # MNGO oracle `\
 --clone FHQtNjRHA9U5ahrH7mWky3gamouhesyQ5QvpeGKrTh2z   `: # BTC Perp market `\
 --clone F1Dcnq6F8NXR3gXADdsYqrXYBUUwoT7pfCtRuQWSyQFd   `: ## bidsKey `\
 --clone BFEBZsLYmEhj4quWDRKbyMKhW1Q9c7gu3LqsnipNGTVn   `: ## asksKey `\
 --clone Bu17U2YdBM9gRrqQ1zD6MpngQBb71RRAAn8dbxoFDSkU   `: ## eventsKey `\
 --clone 58vac8i9QXStG1hpaa4ouwE1X7ngeDjY9oY7R15hcbKJ   `: # SOL Perp market `\
 --clone 7HRgm8iXEDx2TmSETo3Lq9SXkF954HMVKNiq8t5sKvQS   `: ## bidsKey `\
 --clone 4oNxXQv1Rx3h7aNWjhTs3PWBoXdoPZjCaikSThV4yGb8   `: ## asksKey `\
 --clone CZ5MCRvkN38d5pnZDDEEyMiED3drgDUVpEUjkuJq31Kf   `: ## eventsKey `
#  > /dev/null 2>&1 &
```

I run that script once to configure my `localnet`, or to reset it.

You can then start you `solana-local-validator` the usual way, or run the above script each time if you want to have a deterministic environment.

You then call `anchor test --skip-local-validator` to ran your test suit against it (at first I though Anchor would pick up the local `test-ledger` but it doesn’t)

All the accounts come from the mango `ids.rs`

[https://github.com/blockworks-foundation/mango-client-v3/blob/main/src/ids.json](https://github.com/blockworks-foundation/mango-client-v3/blob/main/src/ids.json)


______

One neat thing that you might have caught in the above script, is that to also copy my users accounts and their associated token accounts from the devnet in order to have the right tokens and balances, mints and identities without bothering with mocking :

```
// ...
 --clone TokenkegQfeZyiNwAJbNbGKPFXCWuBvf9Ss623VQ5DA    `: # token program` \
 --clone ATokenGPvbdGVxr1b2hvZbsiqW5xWH25efTNsLJA8knL   `: # assoc token program` \
 --clone aca3VWxwBeu8FTZowJ9hfSKGzntjX68EXh1N9xpE1PC    `: # Acam wallet` \
 --clone 9KBGW5bbfdLA4zKAXPETwjR5Ub7BR2Zh9gKHsPnrUkUg   `: ## BTC assoc token acc` \
 --clone 7CZfVDqqYueBujgvqxwDp7Y29eoe5zcgdcqvsUW5bcqP   `: ## USDC assoc token acc` \
 --clone Eyh77zP5b7arPtPgpnCT8vsGmq9p5Z9HHnBSeQLnAFQi   `: # Test user wallet` \
 --clone C2CmwB1DBgaKUKHUNi9Ua55wKSH12W95wJEe8yMbSzCN   `: ## BTC assoc token acc` \
 --clone gq25cMCGNb9VNquJsqTYNpipUjZbVB6FktQiENvnq7q    `: ## USDC assoc token acc` \ 
// ...
```

You can easily follow Mango tutorial to get Devnet tokens, then go trade these on the devnet Mango for other Sol, BTC and the like (That’s a good way to avoid the devnet sol airdrop limitation 🤫)

[https://docs.mango.markets/tutorials/how-to-receive-dev-net-tokens](https://docs.mango.markets/tutorials/how-to-receive-dev-net-tokens)

All in all, this allows me to send Mango instructions like `InitMangoAccount` successfully.

One last thing that I loose using `anchor test --skip-local-validator` compared to just running `anchor test` is that the deployment does prompt now, not as fast. Will look into that later to understand what’s the diff.


__________

## Anchor and CPI to Mango

Mango is not Anchor friendly, seems normal as the project is big and complex, and has been started from before Anchor. Also they probably don’t want to rely on a WIP framework.

Most of the “issues” here, are not really issues… Just sugar and QoL stuff, subjective.

First issues is that you cannot use the idiomatic Anchor stuff like `Program<‘info, Mango>` as mango did not have a declare_id required by Anchor.

Did a smol PR about it :

[https://github.com/blockworks-foundation/mango-v3/pull/67](https://github.com/blockworks-foundation/mango-v3/pull/67)


_____

### Creating and initialising the MangoAccount

The next thing is that the `mango::state::MangoAccount` has a span of 28912 bytes if I’m not mistaken, preventing you to use the Anchor IDL account creation :

```
    #[account(
        init,
        seeds = [MANGO_SEED, mint.key().as_ref()],
        bump,
        payer = authority,
        owner = mango::mango_program::Mango::id(), // This is my custom stuff added with the PR above
        space = MANGO_ACCOUNT_SPAN, // 28912
    )]
    pub mango_account: AccountInfo<'info>,
```

Results in this error :
`Account data size realloc limited to 10240 in inner instructions`

So I fall back on the associated instruction init as follows :

```
// ... In the Solana program
// signer cause it's required later for the CPI initialization 
#[account(mut, signer)]
pub mango_account: AccountInfo<'info>,
// ...
```

and in the typescript code

```
// ...
   const mangoAccount = new Keypair(); 
   const createMangoAccountIx = SystemProgram.createAccount({
      programId: MANGO_PROGRAM_ID,
      space: MangoAccountLayout.span,
      lamports: await getRentExemption(MangoAccountLayout.span),
      fromPubkey: admin.wallet.publicKey,
      newAccountPubkey: mangoAccount.publicKey, 
    });
    // Then call your program instruction and don't forget the IX + the mangoAccount.secretKey in the signers.
    // instructions: [createMangoAccountIx],
    // signers: [mangoAccount.secretKey],
// ...
```


_____

### Mint-erlude 🥂

For the next “Mango related” part, I will have to stop testing with my locally crafted mints, and start using the actual `devnet` token mints, so that the cloned accounts from the mango program can find their babies.

Here I go on `devnet` , I create a new wallet, fund it with some of the required tokens.

![r i c h](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/C7r_Z4yLnUpTe4oVh9cB3.png?height=352&width=1978)

Next step is to go in the script that setup the local environment for `localnet` and add this new account to the cloning.

```
// ...
--clone Eyh77zP5b7arPtPgpnCT8vsGmq9p5Z9HHnBSeQLnAFQi   `: # Test user wallet` \
// ...
```

Final step, is to go in the program and create the `Keypair` associated to these thanks to the exported Private Key. (We need keypair to sign stuff)

```
// ...
// aca3VWxwBeu8FTZowJ9hfSKGzntjX68EXh1N9xpE1PC
const aca3VWSeed = Uint8Array.from([
  197, 246, ... 146, 223,
]);
// Eyh77zP5b7arPtPgpnCT8vsGmq9p5Z9HHnBSeQLnAFQi
const Eyh77Seed = Uint8Array.from([
  219, 139, ... 212, 175,
]);

// Identities - both of these are wallets that exists on devnet, we clone them in the localnet env
aca3VWxwBeu8FTZowJ9hfSKGzntjX68EXh1N9xpE1PC
export let admin = Keypair.fromSecretKey(aca3VWSeed);
export let user = Keypair.fromSecretKey(Eyh77Seed);
// ...
```

Now I have my test identities that are funded and ready to be used.


_____

title: What exactly is a BITCOIN ETF?
body: Bitcoin etfs have long been a hot topic in encryption. The battle for approval of the country’s first BITCOIN ETF by the Securities and Exchange Commission has been an uphill battle. In the past few months, Crypto’s approval has been boosted by growing support from institutional investors, although none of the funds that have applied to encrypt etfs in the US has received regulatory approval. On Oct. 5, the Securities and Exchange Commission approved an ETF application from Volt Equity, the first bitcoin-related ETF product to be approved in the United States. The ETF will not hold any cryptocurrencies directly and will be made up of stakes in about 30 companies, including MicroStrategy, Tesla, Square, Coinbase and PayPal, your correspondent has learned. Dozens of encrypted etfs are pending approval by the Securities and Exchange Commission, spanning more than eight years. Meanwhile, two countries, Canada and Brazil, have approved encrypted etfs that U.S. citizens can trade through their ROTH accounts. Before applying for a BITCOIN ETF recently, investment manager James Seyffart and his colleague Eric Balchunas pointed out that there was a 75% chance that the SEC would approve the first U.S. bitcoin ETF.

title: Seeing Like a Code: early interactions with DAOs
body:
### Creating new financial and governance systems is a political and social act, not a technocratic solution to an accepted problem, not a technical tool, although that’s where it starts.

*Seeing Like a State* by James C. Scott (1998) opens with the story of the invention of scientific forestry in 18th Century Prussia and Saxony. This is a model and a metaphor for the simplification and manipulation of the world by powerful institutions with sharply defined interests (such as nation states). In the case of forestry, the state’s tunnel vision is focused on resource extraction, translating the ancient forest into measurements of usable timber yield, and missing the other parts of the forest. Then, reshaping (clearing, ordering, replanting) forests to better suit measurement, administration and extraction of that resource. The ordered rows of single-species trees were, of course, catastrophic for the ecosystem.

Top-down planning maps the world according to myopic short term interests. In Scott’s thesis this is the substrate to the tragic episodes of state development through the 20th Century, which combined the aspiration to the administrative ordering of nature and society, the use of power, and a weakened civil society lacking the capacity to resist.

It’s one of those non-fiction books where the author makes their claim and then delivers a regiment of chaptered illustrations in support. (Whisper: *This could have been an email*). I read it because it’s on the reading lists of many in the DAO community, and I’ve been doing a DAO course.

The world needs more larpers writing about DAOs like it needs a hole in the head. Except, such is the global network that the seeming cornucopia of discord servers bursting with DAO discourse represents people and ideas that are still in reality few and siloed.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/xy2hpwcQZZ6-ed3S9TW3Q.jpg?height=1353&width=2595)

A Distributed Autonomous Organisation (DAO) is decentralised and governed around rules enforced on a blockchain. The rules and the organisation are therefore transparent and immutable, open source and trustless. The DAO literature positions a sequence of old governance organisational structures, from tribes to hierarchies to markets, and locates DAOs (and coordinated decentralised decision-making more generally) next to and ripe for a global, post-corporate world.

DAOs have been described as *a discord with a shared bank account.* The majority are organised groups investing in digital assets. There was $10m in DAOs in 2019, and over $1B now. Beyond digital currency wealth, members talk a lot about how they value the community of a DAO.

*Seeing Like a State* is a DAO reading list favourite because it describes repeating failures of centralised top-down organisations and by default seems to welcome the DAO fundamentals of decentralisation, transparency and coordination in decision-making, work, and reward.

But, by another reading of the text, it is the language and methods of measurement that have so effectively shaped the actions and outcomes Scott describes. Decentralised Autonomous Organisations do the same; instead of the metrics of natural resources the language is ***rules that a machine can understand.***

There is a schism between the language of DAOs and the language of the DAOists. Articulate, genius DAOist trailblazers carry me along on their belief that a better way of coordinating is possible and it’s here.

[https://twitter.com/owocki/status/1448016316523286529?s=20](https://twitter.com/owocki/status/1448016316523286529?s=20)

Ewoki GITER of COINS (Kevin Owocki of Github DAO) spoke to my class from Colorado, beautifully, astutely, fluidly. At one point he paused and reminded us: *Well, you know, there are a lot of other aspects grafted onto employment structures we need to consider, security, sick leave and health insurance, pension systems, unions. The old system has some benefits.*

The old system does have some benefits, although not for the globally connected 20-40 year old males who currently constitute the majority of the DAO community. We talk about this, too, the *problem of diversity*, the risk of a narrow group of people building the same infrastructure, following the same best practice applied across the board, with the same assumptions, the same solution to the same reading of the problem.

Even fluidly articulate Owocki shapes his compelling vision around the language of the technology that underpins it. Around tools, plug-ins, applications, perpetual rules that can’t be compromised, the ‘if then…’ clarity of the coder’s direction, the ability to fix scalability and coordination problems with clever technology.

[https://twitter.com/owocki/status/1448334880043982849?s=20](https://twitter.com/owocki/status/1448334880043982849?s=20)

DAOs will continue to grow and evolve out of their early experimental phases and into more mainstream adoption in coordinating groups with common aims and shared resources. Right now, the actions of setting up a DAO and programming it (through an absolute *launch* of beta tools) to accept member proposals, enable member votes, allocate funds, distribute shares, measure workload and contribution, track sentiment, manage communications, set up admission protocols, cultivate \*culture\*.  Rules so specific they can be interpreted by a machine, trying to play catch up to the ideas.

My attempt to use (obey?) a discord bot to set up token distribution to digital wallets feels like moving too fast through a dark cave and then it feels like failure.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/0GBuY9UlCGr5to2w2-iMe.PNG?height=1334&width=750)

The DAO course was terrific, by the way, the best 20 HAUS tokens I have ever spent.

Some people have issues with DAOs because of their cypto-currency adjacency, because (currently) their primary use is to fuel group speculation on digital assets and (ideally) generate monthly salaries in hours for their members. To the extent that they solve problems, they’re mostly solving the problem that crypto created for itself. That will run its course and the philosophy and systems of decentralisation will morph as other goals find purpose and function within them. But now, at the beginning of the structuring of this system/s, we are talking about social benefits in a small echo chamber through the rigid language of code.

I told my boss at work about DAOs, but he hadn’t heard of a blockchain and the string between TradFi and DeFi was stretched too far. He said: *I hope they remember all of us old fashioned people in this future.* I agree, please don’t leave me behind, but on the other hand, TradFi never worried about those it excluded either.

[https://twitter.com/owocki/status/1448016316523286529?s=20](https://twitter.com/owocki/status/1448016316523286529?s=20)

Ewoki GITER of COINS (Kevin Owocki of Github DAO) spoke to my class from Colorado, beautifully, astutely, fluidly. At one point he paused and reminded us: *Well, you know, there are a lot of other aspects grafted onto employment structures we need to consider, security, sick leave and health insurance, pension systems, unions. The old system has some benefits.*

The old system does have some benefits, although not for the globally connected 20-40 year old males who currently constitute the majority of the DAO community. We talk about this, too, the *problem of diversity*, the risk of a narrow group of people building the same infrastructure, following the same best practice applied across the board, with the same assumptions, the same solution to the same reading of the problem.

Even fluidly articulate Owocki shapes his compelling vision around the language of the technology that underpins it. Around tools, plug-ins, applications, perpetual rules that can’t be compromised, the ‘if then…’ clarity of the coder’s direction, the ability to fix scalability and coordination problems with clever technology.

[https://twitter.com/owocki/status/1448334880043982849?s=20](https://twitter.com/owocki/status/1448334880043982849?s=20)

DAOs will continue to grow and evolve out of their early experimental phases and into more mainstream adoption in coordinating groups with common aims and shared resources. Right now, the actions of setting up a DAO and programming it (through an absolute *launch* of beta tools) to accept member proposals, enable member votes, allocate funds, distribute shares, measure workload and contribution, track sentiment, manage communications, set up admission protocols, cultivate \*culture\*.  Rules so specific they can be interpreted by a machine, trying to play catch up to the ideas.

My attempt to use (obey?) a discord bot to set up token distribution to digital wallets feels like moving too fast through a dark cave and then it feels like failure.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/0GBuY9UlCGr5to2w2-iMe.PNG?height=1334&width=750)

The DAO course was terrific, by the way, the best 20 HAUS tokens I have ever spent.

Some people have issues with DAOs because of their cypto-currency adjacency, because (currently) their primary use is to fuel group speculation on digital assets and (ideally) generate monthly salaries in hours for their members. To the extent that they solve problems, they’re mostly solving the problem that crypto created for itself. That will run its course and the philosophy and systems of decentralisation will morph as other goals find purpose and function within them. But now, at the beginning of the structuring of this system/s, we are talking about social benefits in a small echo chamber through the rigid language of code.

I told my boss at work about DAOs, but he hadn’t heard of a blockchain and the string between TradFi and DeFi was stretched too far. He said: *I hope they remember all of us old fashioned people in this future.* I agree, please don’t leave me behind, but on the other hand, TradFi never worried about those it excluded either.

title: Mango integration, localnet testing and Anchor CPI to non Anchor programs
body:
So lately I’ve been tasked to integrate the Solana Program I’m working on with Mango.
I want to gather the knowledge and tidbits that I find valuable in case that can be of use.

*Sky Burial #2 by Wayne Haag, because space derelicts stuff look cool*


______

Mango is a decentralised exchange (DEX) that offer leveraged trading and perpetuals.

Mango is managed by a DAO and seems like a great functional example of decentralised governance.

And most importantly, it’s a neat product I use since months, my main DEX. Neat features and UI, smooth UX.


_____

## Localnet dev environment with --clone

In order to be productive, I want to iterate quickly.

Mango is currently accessible on `devnet` and `main-net` clusters, but my anchor workspace contains several projects, that I modify often, so I don’t feel like using `devnet`.

I want to be able to have my usual `anchor test` speed, not sure what happen behind the curtain but the deployments to `localnet` don’t event appear in the prompt, making it ideal for iterating fast.

In order to use Mango on `localnet` I found this neat option for `solana-test-validator` (the program running `localnet` coming with the Solana cli) :

`--clone <account>`  (credits to dvcrn#7961 on the Anchor discord)

It copies accounts from another cluster into the starting `localnet` instance, and note that once you run the `solana-local-validator` once, it create a `test-ledger` folder that store its state. So `--clone` only have effect when this `test-ledger` is not there, of if you use `--reset` to start fresh.

This is how I use it :

```
#!/bin/bash

# Reset then configure the local validator to mimic the mango accounts on devnet
solana-test-validator \
 --reset                                                `: # Reset the test-ledger` \
 --url https://mango.devnet.rpcpool.com                 `: # Cluster from which the below program will be cloned` \
 --clone TokenkegQfeZyiNwAJbNbGKPFXCWuBvf9Ss623VQ5DA    `: # token program` \
 --clone 8mFQbdXsFXt3R3cu3oSNS3bDZRwJRP18vyzd9J278J9z   `: # cache `\
 --clone ATokenGPvbdGVxr1b2hvZbsiqW5xWH25efTNsLJA8knL   `: # assoc token program` \
 --clone aca3VWxwBeu8FTZowJ9hfSKGzntjX68EXh1N9xpE1PC    `: # Acam wallet` \
 --clone 9KBGW5bbfdLA4zKAXPETwjR5Ub7BR2Zh9gKHsPnrUkUg   `: ## BTC assoc token acc` \
 --clone 7CZfVDqqYueBujgvqxwDp7Y29eoe5zcgdcqvsUW5bcqP   `: ## USDC assoc token acc` \
 --clone 4uv1EwgZNa91tnBbr49KrQmpb29mp95e9ATh77tgxr6B   `: ## WSOL assoc token acc` \
 --clone Eyh77zP5b7arPtPgpnCT8vsGmq9p5Z9HHnBSeQLnAFQi   `: # Test user wallet` \
 --clone C2CmwB1DBgaKUKHUNi9Ua55wKSH12W95wJEe8yMbSzCN   `: ## BTC assoc token acc` \
 --clone gq25cMCGNb9VNquJsqTYNpipUjZbVB6FktQiENvnq7q    `: ## USDC assoc token acc` \
 --clone 92jBUBivpzTu5EEtdVgKXXwmEhfqFMsg91z2RRYyobFQ   `: ## WSOL assoc token acc` \
 --clone 8FRFC6MoGGkMFQwngccyu69VnYbzykGeez7ignHVAFSN   `: # USDC mango test TOKEN MINT followed by mango root/node` \
 --clone HUBX4iwWEUK5VrXXXcB7uhuKrfT4fpu2T9iZbg712JrN \
 --clone J2Lmnc1e4frMnBEJARPoHtfpcohLfN67HdK1inXjTFSM \
 --clone 3UNBZ6o52WTWwjac2kPUb4FyodhU1vFkRJheu1Sh2TvU   `: # BTC TOKEN MINT followed by mango root/node`\
 --clone BeEoyDq1v2DYJCoXDQAJKfmrsoRRvfmV856f2ijkXbtp \
 --clone 4X3nP921qyh6BKJSAohKGNCykSXahFFwg1LxtC993Fai \
 --clone Bb9bsTQa1bGEtQ5KagGkvSHyuLqDWumFUcRqFusFNJWC   `: # Mango TOKEN MINT followed by mango root/node` \
 --clone CY4nMV9huW5KCYFxWChrmoLwGCsZiXoiREeo2PMrBm5o \
 --clone 6rkPNJTXF37X6Pf5ct5Y6E91PozpZpZNNU1AGATomKjD \
 --clone So11111111111111111111111111111111111111112    `: # WSOL TOKEN MINT followed by mango root/node` \
 --clone 8GC81raaLjhTx3yedctxCJW46qdmmSRybH2s1eFYFFxT \
 --clone 7mYqCavd1K24fnL3oKTpX3YM66W5gfikmVHJWM3nrWKe \
 --clone Ec2enZyoC4nGpEfu2sUNAa2nUGJHWxoUWYSEJ2hNTWTA   `: # MANGO starts - devnet.2 cluster `\
 --clone 4skJ85cdxQAFVKbcGgfun8iZPL7BadVYXG3kGEGkufqA   `: # mangoProgramId `\
 --clone 79Rz9FwjTYSGMbpPBbQMT6kEmqhuGvhqpCPEoALJGmsb   `: # vault? `\
 --clone 6eadH6vSsEk5bPiXWPYRq5KRSjohfYd6Ug5HjGbxaWce \
 --clone DESVgJVGajEgKGXhb6XmqDHGz3VjdgP7rEVESBgxmroY   `: # serumProgramId`\
 --clone AvKzLiE8ezzp6kLVw49nq8drycE89NS1RQaBWjBNeUoF \
 --clone HovQMDrbAgAYPCmHVSrezcSmkMtXSSUsLDFANExrZh2J   `: # BTC oracle `\
 --clone J83w4HKfqxwcq3BEMMkPFSppX3gqekLyLJBexebFVkix   `: # SOL oracle `\
 --clone 8k7F9Xb36oFJsjpCKpsXvg4cgBRoZtwNTc3EzG5Ttd2o   `: # MNGO oracle `\
 --clone FHQtNjRHA9U5ahrH7mWky3gamouhesyQ5QvpeGKrTh2z   `: # BTC Perp market `\
 --clone F1Dcnq6F8NXR3gXADdsYqrXYBUUwoT7pfCtRuQWSyQFd   `: ## bidsKey `\
 --clone BFEBZsLYmEhj4quWDRKbyMKhW1Q9c7gu3LqsnipNGTVn   `: ## asksKey `\
